Title: How to prove $f \in L^p(0,1)$
Content:
Let $f \ge 0$ , $f\in L^1(0,1)$ , monotone decrease. Suppose $\forall a,x \in (0,1) $ such that $0<x-a<x+a<1$ , $$\int_{x-a}^x f(t)dt<\frac{5}{4} \int_{x}^{x+a}f(t)dt.$$ Prove $f\in L^p(0,1)$ , $\forall 1\le p\le \frac{\ln 2}{\ln 3-\ln 2}$ . I can get a weaker bound $1\le p<\frac{\ln 2}{\ln25 - \ln16}$ by dividing the interval of integration by $[2^{-n},2^{-n+1}]$ and getting $f(2^{-n})<\frac{25}{16}f(2^{-n+1})$ , but I don't know how to get a finer bound. My attempt, $$
2^{-n}f(2^{-n})<\int_0^{2^{-n}} f(t)dt<\frac{5}{4}\int_{2^{-n}} ^{2^{-n+1}} f(t)dt<\frac{25}{16}\int_{2^{-n+1}} ^{2^{-n+2}} f(t)dt<2^{-n}f(2^{-n+1}),
$$ thus, $$f(2^{-n})<\frac{25}{16}f(2^{-n+1})<\left(\frac{25}{16}\right)^nf(1).$$ Then, $$
\int_0^1 f(t)^p<\sum_{n=0}^{+\infty}2^{-n}f(2^{-n})^p<f(1)^p\sum_{n=0}^{+\infty}\left(\frac{25}{16}\right)^{np}\cdot2^{-n},
$$ if $\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{25}{16}\right)^p<1$ , we can get $\int_0^1 f(t)^p<+\infty$ .
AcceptedAnswer: If we follow OP's idea, the issue seems is at the last step of $$x f(x) \le \int_{0}^x f(t) dt \le A\int_{x}^{2x} f(t) dt \le A^2 \int_{2x}^{3x} f(t) dt$$ where $A = \frac{5}{4}$ . This step relaxes too much. Since the inequality is applied twice. So maybe a good strategy is to use once. That is $$ \int_{0}^x f(t) dt \le A\int_{x}^{2x} f(t) dt \le A x f(x). $$ While the LHS is $$ \int_{0}^x f(t) dt = \int_{0}^{x/2} f(t) dt + \int_{x/2}^x f(t) dt \ge \frac{x}{2} f(\frac{x}{2}) + \frac{x}{2} f(x) $$ Therefore $$(2 A - 1) f(x) \ge f(\frac{x}{2})$$ which means $$\frac{3}{2} f(x) \ge f(\frac{x}{2}). $$ Then follow OP's steps, it is done. Followup. To find a better $p$ , one can set $$ \int_{0}^x f(t) dt = \int_{0}^{\beta x/2} f(t) dt + \int_{\beta x/2}^x f(t) dt \ge \frac{\beta x}{2} f(\frac{\beta x}{2}) + (1-\frac{\beta}{2})x f(x) $$ Thus $$\left(A - 1 +\frac{\beta}{2}\right) f(x) \ge \frac{\beta}{2} f(\frac{\beta x}{2})$$ then convergence means $$\left|\frac{2A - 2 + \beta}{\beta}\right|^p \frac{\beta}{2} < 1\Rightarrow p < \frac{\log(2/\beta)}{\log(0.5+\beta)/\beta}$$ The maximum is at $\beta = 0.5$ (because of this :)) which makes $p < 2$ .
